intro: Torreyochloa pallida subsp. viridis, commonly known as green sand grass, is a perennial grass species native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, wiry stems and narrow, grass-like leaves that are typically green in color. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear minute, wind-dispersed seeds. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the grass family, Poaceae, with ecological significance in its native habitats.
